case_name: Inspector of Factories, Bhavnagar v. Kansara Manilal Bhikhalal

facts.text: On June 21, 1960, at 5-50 A.M. the Inspector of Factories, Bhavnagar, visited Saurashtra Metal and Mechanical Works, Wadhwan City

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1960, at 5-50 A.M. the Inspector of Factories, Bhavnagar, visited Saurashtra Metal and Mechanical Works, Wadhwan City,

facts.text: Saurashtra Metal and Mechanical Works, Wadhwan City, is a factory within the meaning of s. 2 m i of Factories Act, 1948

anchor.surface_text: which is a factory within the meaning of s. 2 m  i  of Factories Act, 1948.

facts.text: Inspector found seven workmen working on a machine

anchor.surface_text: He found seven workmen working on a machine and on examining the numberice of period of work for adult workers

facts.text: Three of the workmen belonged to a group which was expected to begin work from 7 A.M.

anchor.surface_text: the register of workers he found that three of the workmen belonged to a group which was expected to begin work from 7 A.M.

facts.text: Proceedings commenced under s. 63 of the Factories Act 1948 against the respondent Mr. Kansara Manilal Bhikhalal as the occupier manager

anchor.surface_text: He companymenced proceedings under s. 63 of the Factories Act 1948 against the respondent Mr. Kansara Manilal Bhikhalal as the occupier manager of the factory,

facts.text: Notice to show cause issued to respondent

anchor.surface_text: after issuing numberice to him to show cause.

facts.text: Enhanced penalty under s. 94 sought because Mr. Manilal Bhikhalal was convicted on a previous occasion in three cases

anchor.surface_text: He asked for enhanced penalty under s. 94 of the Factories Act because the said Mr. Manilal Bhikhalal was companyvicted on a previous occasion in three cases.

facts.text: Three separate complaints filed in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Wadhwan City

anchor.surface_text: As three workmen were companycerned three separate companyplaints were filed in the Court of the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Wadhwan City.

facts.text: Respondent claimed he was not the occupier and manager of the factory

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the respondent was that he was number the occupier and manager of the factory.

facts.text: Respondent and Mr. Dangi are partners with another factory at Dharangadhra

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that one Mr. Dangi and the respondent are partners. They have another factory at Dharangadhra

facts.text: Mr. Bhikhalal was manager at Dharangadhra factory and Mr. Dangi at Wadhwan

anchor.surface_text: and the defence was that Mr. Bhikhalal was manager at the Dharangadhra factory and Mr. Dangi was managers at Wadhwan.

facts.text: A machine had gone out of order the previous day and after repair work started earlier

anchor.surface_text: Another defence was that a machine had gone out of order the previous day and after it was repaired work was started a little earlier the next day,

facts.text: Inspector informed by letter Ext. 11 written on the 20th about change of timing, reached on 22nd

anchor.surface_text: because production had suffered and goods were required. The Inspector, it was stated, was informed by a letter  Ext. 11  written on the 20th about the change of timing though the letter,

facts.text: Change in hours of work was not notified and displayed as required by s. 61(1)

anchor.surface_text: unfortunately, did number reach the Inspector till the 22nd. It was admitted that this change in the hours of work was number numberified and displayed

facts.text: Judicial Magistrate did not accept defences

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Magistrate did number accept these defences.

facts.text: Mr. Dangi's letter Ext. 15 showed respondent was occupier and manager

anchor.surface_text: According to him, Mr. Dangis letter  Ext. 15  showed that the respondent was the occupier and the manager of the factory at Wadhwan.

facts.text: Respondent convicted under s. 63 for three offences, fine Rs. 100 each under s. 94

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was, therefore, companyvicted under s. 63 of the Factories Act in respect of three offences and under s. 94, enhanced punishment was imposed upon him by ordering him to pay a fine of Rs. 100 in respect of each offence.

facts.text: Sessions Judge of Surendranagar acquitted respondent on appeal

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Sessions Judge of Surendranagar ordered the acquittal of the respondent.

facts.text: State of Gujarat appealed against acquittal to High Court but unsuccessful

anchor.surface_text: The State of Gujarat appealed against the acquittal but was unsuccessful.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court agreed with Sessions Judge on s. 61(10), no opinion on s. 117

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the High Court which heard the appeal agreed with the Sessions Judge in his interpretation of s. 61 10  and did number express any opinion on s. 117 of the Act.

facts.text: Appeal filed by special leave of this Court

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal filed by special leave of this Court these two points have again arisen for our companysideration.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside acquittal and convicts respondent under s. 63 read with s. 94, sentenced to pay fine

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, set aside his acquittal and companyvict him under s. 63 read with s. 94 of the Factories Act. He is sentenced to pay a fine of Rs.

issues.text: Whether the respondent was the occupier and manager of the factory

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us that the respondent was not the occupier manager of the factory and, in any event, s. 117 of the Act protected him because he was not present there and his action was bonafide.

issues.text: Whether an offence under s. 63 of the Factories Act was committed

anchor.surface_text: under s. 63 of the Factories Act 1948 against the respondent Mr. Kansara Manilal Bhikhalal as the occupier manager of the factory, after issuing notice to him to show cause. He asked for enhanced penalty under s. 94 of the Factories Act because

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 61(10) were complied with so as to avoid offence under s. 63

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge held that the second part of a s. 61 10  applied to a case of second or subsequent change and this being the first change it did not fall within the second part. According to the Sessions Judge, it fell in the first part of the sub-section and the change could not be said to have been effected in breach of that part since the Inspector of Factories was informed about the change.

issues.text: Whether s. 117 of the Factories Act provides protection to the respondent

anchor.surface_text: s. 117 of the Act protected him because he was not present there and his action was bonafide. As to the first part of this argument it is sufficient to say that the Magistrate found that he was the occupier and manager. The letter of Mr. Dangi  Ext. 15  quite clearly establishes this.

issues.text: Whether enhanced penalty under s. 94 applies due to previous conviction

anchor.surface_text: enhanced penalty under s. 94 of the Factories Act because the said Mr. Manilal Bhikhalal was convicted on a previous occasion in three cases. issues.text: Whether the respondent is entitled to exemption under s. 101

anchor.surface_text: exempted from liability in certain cases mentioned in s. 101. Where an occupier or a manager is charged with an offence he is entitled to make a complaint in his own turn against any person who was the actual offender

holdings.text: The respondent was the occupier and manager of the factory as found by the Magistrate and established by Mr. Dangi's letter Ext. 15.

anchor.surface_text: As to the first part of this argument it is sufficient to say that the Magistrate found that he was the occupier and manager. The letter of Mr. Dangi  Ext. 15  quite clearly establishes this.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Magistrate's finding based on documentary evidence Ext. 15 rejecting respondent's denial.

holdings.text: Section 61(10) of the Factories Act contemplates changes in the system of work necessitating a recast of the notice under s.61(1), not casual changes in hours of individual workers, and implies such changes should not be frequent.

anchor.surface_text: With due respect to the High Court, we do not agree that this sort of case is contemplated by the tenth sub-section. That sub-section speaks of change in the system of work in any factory which will necessitate a change in the notice

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation distinguishes system-wide changes from individual departures; latter part restricts frequency.

holdings.text: Employment of workers contrary to the notice under s.61(1) without exemption under s.64 rules constitutes an offence under s.63 of the Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: It would, therefore, appear that the offence which was committed in the case was the employment of workers contrary to the notice displayed under s. 61(1) without any justification by reason of any exempting provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.59 overtime read harmoniously with s.64 exempting rules; no departure from notice permitted otherwise; s.61(10) inapplicable.

holdings.text: Section 117 protects only good faith acts or omissions done or intended under the Act, not contraventions or breaches even if bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: The protection conferred can only be claimed by a person who can plead that he was required to do or omit to do something under the Act or that he intended to comply with any of its provisions. It cannot confer immunity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of 'done or intended to be done under this Act'; requires compliance or intended compliance, not violations; distinguishes precedents.

holdings.text: Enhanced penalty under s.94 applies due to previous convictions, convicting respondent under s.63 read with s.94.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, set aside his acquittal and convict him under s. 63 read with s. 94 of the Factories Act. He is sentenced to pay a fine of Rs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous convictions established; applies penal provisions post-finding of offence under s.63.
